Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Evolutionary trade-offs in the adaptation of decomposers to global warming: Implications for ecosystem C balance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soil fungi responsible for the decay and recycling of carbon may evolve in response to global warming. This could have serious consequences with respect to global change. This team of investigators posit that warmer temperatures may favor the evolution of fungi that can break down material that is long-lived(?recalcitrant?) in the soil . As a consequence, more greenhouse gases would be released to the atmosphere in a feedback loop that could lead to even warmer temperatures. This issue is particularly urgent in the northern, boreal forests of Alaska, which store large amounts of recalcitrant matter in their soils, and which are warming more rapidly than elsewhere. Research team members will be simulating global warming in such forests and examining its effects on fungi and their degradation activities. In addition, they will be exposing fungi to warming in laboratory experiments that will use genetic and physiological tests to examine how their ability to decompose recalcitrant materials changes over time.

Human life cannot exist without fungi to decompose organic matter, since they recycle nutrients from dead organisms for use by plants, animals, and people. This study will provide explicit predictions of the different ways that global warming maybe affecting fungi. It will also be one of the first to examine the evolution of these microbes in response to global warming. In addition, the investigators will train one postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students and several undergraduate researchers, with an emphasis on recruitment of students from underrepresented groups in science. The investigators will also invite students and teachers from a nearby elementary school to participate in day-long mushroom forays and a global change field trip.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polar bears are not the only indicators of climate change. In fact, one of the biggest indicators is a lot smaller and can be found right beneath our feet. These invisible agents of climate change are fungi.

Fungi are an important type of microbe found within the soil. They recycle nutrients after breaking down dead material from plants and animals. However, when they recycle these nutrients, they release carbon dioxide—a greenhouse gas—into the atmosphere. But, to what degree can an invisible organism affect a global phenomenon like climate change?

Although they are quite influential, fungi are not immune to the effects of warming. They too are sensitive to temperature. And depending on how they respond, they could release more carbon dioxide.

Fungi break down two types of carbon—“tasty” and “not so tasty”. Think of a warm chocolate chip cookie and crunchy, fibrous celery. The cookie is sugary and melts in your mouth. The celery is more difficult to chew. Although fungi can use both, they are powerhouses in breaking down difficult forms of carbon. If fungi become more active with warmer temperatures they may break down more of this “not so tasty” carbon. This feedback could lead to greater carbon dioxide emissions.

But, do warmer temperatures make it easier for fungi to use carbon? That is the question that Dr. Kathleen Treseder, Dr. Steven Allison, and Dr. John Taylor were on the hunt to find out.

To answer this question, they looked to the boreal forests of Alaska. Soils within these forests have a lot of carbon that is difficult to break down. On top of this, they are warming faster than most other ecosystems. As these frozen soils thaw, the carbon within them becomes accessible. Depending on how fungi respond, this could be an unfortunate combination.

They performed this research in a three-year project funded by the National Science Foundation. The main goals of the study were to find out if fungi would evolve in response to global warming, and to get a better idea of what this could mean for carbon cycling. This is important information missing from many climate models. Fungi are doing a lot of the work, but not getting a lot of credit in our climate models. If they continue to be overlooked, modelers may make inaccurate predications. The research team was determined to improve this.

Researchers try to answer these questions by looking at specific levels of biology. These include the molecular (focusing on small molecules), physiological (how organisms function), evolutionary (long-term changes that occur in populations), and ecosystem (includes the large-scale environment) levels. This is one of the first times all of these levels have been incorporated into one project.

Moreover, the study involved both field and lab experiments. In Alaska, the team has greenhouses that have been warming the soil for nine years. Back at UC Irvine and UC Berkeley, the team was keeping fungi at different temperatures to see if they would evolve. This combination would allow them to dig deep into how fungi might change with warming.

Fungi release enzymes, which are small molecules that break apart carbon so it can be recycled. Enzymes are specialized to break down specific types of carbon—including the difficult, “not so tasty” types. The team determined how active these enzymes were at warmer temperatures.

What happens when fungi are evolved to warmer temperatures? The team determined that fungi produce enzymes that only work at the specific temperatures they are exposed to. In fact, they lost the ability to produce working enzymes at any other temperature. Essentially, they became experts at their designated temperatures. Likewise, if fungi were evolved to warmer temperatures, they had a better ability to break down difficult forms of carbon. Overall, there seems to be a strong evolutionary force that drives responses to warming.

Furthermore, this project included more than critical research. There were important outreach components as well. For instance, Elizabeth Niehaus, an undergraduate and intern for the Center for Environmental Biology, developed lesson plans for elementary school kids on why fungi are important. There was also a monitoring experiment in Crystal Cove, where students learned how to identify fungi.

Consequently, the team showed that fungi need to get more credit in climate models. This project provides a better understanding of the mechanisms behind how fungi respond to warming. In turn, this can improve model projections.

According to Romero-Olivares, the study shows that “in the microbial world everything is possible, including evolution within a year.” She points out that this will have “a huge impact on the way that we think of global climate change and on the way that we should prepare for future climate.” Overall, this work makes fungi less invisible. And instead makes them a powerful tool in understanding future climate change.

-Written by Caitlin Looby
